properties.media:imagetext:
November 7, 1936.
Mrs. H. M. Bixby,
51 Canton Road,
Shanghai, China.
Dear Mrs. Bixby:
I
was delighted to get your letter today
and to know that you had received the envelopes
and my
letters.
I
an afraid that I'm giving you all a lot of
bother and certainly those covers are a nuisance,
and I
often tell myself that I'm through with them but
they
are
sort of fascinating too and the thought and
time
I waste on
them does seem to rest me when I'm tired from worrying over
more weighty matters.
It will
be sort of
a relief
flight is to take place
and
when we know when the first
where the China
terminus is to
be, but I suppose that wheels within wheels revolve slowly -
in any case I've sort of sprinkled my covers all
over the
may and hope you will not have too much difficulty in hand-
ling them.
I'm sorry the unofficial flight to Hong Kong did not carry mail.
I had some covers made for that flight printed from linoleum
blocks in
three colors that I
I'11 have a chance to use them later.
thought interesting - possibly
I am enclosing these pictures clipped from envelopes
as well
as some that I have had made for the Eucharistic Congress
stamy issue.
I am
also
enclosing
two
covers of the first pay passenger
flight - hope you like them.
We have been here a month now and find the time passing very
fast.
We have spent most
of it with our daughter who has just
had her second son, Whipple Hall Manning, and of course we are
all very happy and proud as can be.
Mrs. Hall joins me in kindest regards to you all.
Yours very sincerely,
244 Lakeside Drive,
Oakland, Califomia.
properties.wof:name: correspondence: Mrs. H.M. (Debby) Bixby
